jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": {"code": "emo", "name": "Emok", "change_request": "2013-012", "effective": "2014-02-03", "reason": "non-existent", "change_to": [], "remedy": null, "comment": "Susnik's widespread hypothesis has been disproved: she proposed that the Toba of
Puerto Casado constitute a mixed ethnic group, of "Toba [Qom] groups who blended
with the Maskoy, forming the new Emok-Toba ethnic identity. The first generation
was bilingual, but the Toba language later became established as the 'language
of men'" (Susnik 1989: 144), and supposedly went on to form "a 'Maskoyized'
proletariat in the tannin factories" of Puerto Casado (ibid.). Our research
leaves no doubt that the indigenous population of the tannin ports on the River
Paraguay is of purely Enlhet-Enenlhet descendency. In spite of the existence of
communities such as Cerrito and El Padernal where people of Enlhet- Enenlhet and
Qom descendency live together, bilingualism across the two language groups has
not developed, and Guarani is the main language of intercommunication. That is,
an Emok language (classified as extinct) in fact never existed. Emmo'ok is not
the name of a language; it means simply 'our neighbour' in the languages of the
Enlhet-Enenlhet family. This explains why we have found no instances of a
supposed Emok language; nor of any evidence shown by Susnik, who made her
hypothesis for its existence so widely known."}, "ethnologue_comment": null, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3501762", "label": null}, {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emok_language", "label": null}], "meds": [["500677", "wordlist_or_less", 2013, 0, "ISO 639-3 Registration Authority 2013"]]}
name: Emok

[jua], Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz] and Karipúna (if it refers to Kawahib-Karipuna) [kuq] all speak easily mutually intelligible varieties
(**hh:hvw:Sampaio:Tupi-Kawahib**, **hh:e:Levi-Strauss:Tupi-Cawahib**, **hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**, **hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**, **hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**),
as also acknowledged by the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries themselves whose regions, dialects and speaker numbers overlap.  Paranawát [paf] is a name for a people of the same complex met with (and attested by wordlists) by the Rondon commission
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**). Morerebi [xmo] is an uncontacted group of the Rio Preto and Marmelos, who speak another variety of the this language, if they still exist (**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**).
Wiraféd [wir], also known as Tupi do Machado or Bocas Pretas, is amply attested in wordlists from the past century
(**hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Maue**, **hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hw:Nimuendaju:Icana**, **hh:w:Hanke:Parintintin**, **hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**)
and is hardly distinguishable from Apiaká [api]
(**hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**:222-223,
**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**), which also is so close that it could also count as the Kawahib-language. See also: Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah]."}, "links": [{"url": "http://endangeredlanguages.com/lang/662", "label": "Júma"}, {"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q12953587", "label": null}, {"url": "https://phoible.org/languages/juma1249", "label": null}, {"url": "https://wals.info/languoid/lect/wals_code_jum", "label": "Júma"}], "meds": [["29882", "phonology_or_text", 1984, 18, "Abrahamson, Arne and Abrahamson, Joyce 1984"], ["68251", "phonology_or_text", 1968, 11, "Abrahamson, Arne 1968"]]}
name: Júma

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "kgm", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "A major confusion in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 is with the languages called Karipuna. In addition to Karipuna Creole French [kmv] (an entry which is correct), there are two entries, both classified as Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI:

| p{4cm}} | Karipúna [kgm] | Karipuna [kuq] |
| Region: | Amapá, on French Guiana border | Rondônia, Acre, banks of Jaru, Jamery, Urupa, Cabecciras, Candeias, and Jaciparana rivers. |
| Classification: | Tupi, Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI | Tupi, Tupi-Guarani, Subgroup VI |
| Alternate names: | Karipúna do Amapá, Karipúna do Uaçá | Caripuna, Jau-Navo, Juanauo, Kagwahiva, Karipuná de Rondônia, Karipuná do Guaporé |
| Population: | Extinct. | 14 (2004 ISA). |
| Language use: | Shifted to Karipúna Creole French [kmv]. | Some may also use Tenharim [pah] |


Early references to the Karipuna (or similar names) of Amapá refer to a variety of Palikúr [plu]
(**hh:he:GalloisRicardo:Amapa-Norte-Para**:62). The language of the Karipuna of Amapá in this sense is attested with a short wordlist,
and is indeed a Palikúr [plu] variety (**hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**).
More recent references to the Karipuna of Amapá refer to an immigrant group whose original language is not attested, but, is reported to have been Nheengatu [yrl] (**hh:e:Arnaud:Uaca**,
**hh:he:GalloisRicardo:Amapa-Norte-Para**:62).  Except for the classification and the fact that Nheengatu [yrl] already has an entry,
the Karipúna [kgm] entry is consistent with referring to the more recent Karipuna of Amapá. Thus, whatever it refers to, the same language already has a different E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entry, either Palikur [plu]
or Nheengatu [yrl].

Until the 1950s (**hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**:40-45, 199-213) the only language called Karipuna in the Madeira-Guaporé region was a Panoan language also known as Jau-Navo, amply attested in wordlists
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**, **hh:hv:deCrequi-MontfortRivet:Pano**, **hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**, **hh:w:Hanke:Karipuna**). However,
the name started to be applied to groups of hostile indians at the Mutumparaná and Jaciparaná which were contacted in the 1950-1970s
(**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**:104) and turned out to speak a Tupi-Guarani language of Subgroup VI
(**hh:hv:Mello:Tupi-Guarani:2000**, **hh:w:Monserrat:Amondawa**, **hh:w:Betts:Kagwahiva**),
which we may call Kawahib. FUNAI frivolously used the name Karipuna for this Kawahib group (**hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**:45), encouraging the confusion we now observe. The Karipuna [kuq] entry mixes information from the Panoan Karipuna (e.g., the name Jau-Navo) and the Kawahib Karipuna (e.g., the classification). The Panoan Karipuna is otherwise missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 whereas the Kawahib Karipuna speak the same language as the language of several other entries. See also: Karipúna Creole French [kmv], Karipúna [kuq], Nhengatu [yrl], Palikúr [plu], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah]."}, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q6371069", "label": null}, {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karipuna_language_(Amap%C3%A1)", "label": null}], "meds": [["128003", "wordlist_or_less", 1998, 0, "Tassinari, Antonella Maria Imperatriz 1998"], ["155047", "wordlist_or_less", 1953, 24, "Malcher, J. 1953"]]}
name: Karipuna do Amapa

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": {"code": "mhh", "name": "Maskoy Pidgin", "change_request": "2013-011", "effective": "2014-02-03", "reason": "non-existent", "change_to": [], "remedy": null, "comment": "There is no evidence to show that this language has ever existed. Different
ethnic groups of the Enlhet-Enenlhet (or Maskoy) family certainly have lived
together in the Puerto La Victoria area (just as in several other regions of the
Chaco), but, as we observe in these contexts today (and as witnesses indicate
regarding the Puerto La Victoria region in the past), no type of pidgin has
developed. Either a dominant language has been used by all, or members of each
group have used their own language and the others have developed the ability to
understand it (a passive bi- or multilingualism). In addition, in areas of
contact between Enlhet-Enenlhet languages, the ethnic groups of this family have
quickly begun to speak Guarani with each other. In any case, today no
Enlhet-Enenlhet language is spoken in the Puerto La Victoria region; ethnic
groups belonging to the Enlhet-Enenlhet speak an adapted version of Paraguayan
Guarani."}, "ethnologue_comment": null, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q13581204", "label": null}], "meds": [["500586", "wordlist_or_less", 2013, 0, "ISO 639-3 Registration Authority 2013"]]}
name: Maskoy Pidgin

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "xmo", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "Of the languages of Tupi-Guarani subgroup VII,
there is considerable overdifferentiation.  Júma or Arara-Kawahib
[jua], Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz] and Karipúna (if it refers to Kawahib-Karipuna) [kuq] all speak easily mutually intelligible varieties
(**hh:hvw:Sampaio:Tupi-Kawahib**, **hh:e:Levi-Strauss:Tupi-Cawahib**, **hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**, **hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**, **hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**),
as also acknowledged by the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries themselves whose regions, dialects and speaker numbers overlap.  Paranawát [paf] is a name for a people of the same complex met with (and attested by wordlists) by the Rondon commission
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**). Morerebi [xmo] is an uncontacted group of the Rio Preto and Marmelos, who speak another variety of the this language, if they still exist (**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**).
Wiraféd [wir], also known as Tupi do Machado or Bocas Pretas, is amply attested in wordlists from the past century
(**hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Maue**, **hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hw:Nimuendaju:Icana**, **hh:w:Hanke:Parintintin**, **hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**)
and is hardly distinguishable from Apiaká [api]
(**hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**:222-223,
**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**), which also is so close that it could also count as the Kawahib-language. See also: Amundava [adw], Apiaká [api], Júma [jua], Karipúna [kuq], Paranawát [paf], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz], Wiraféd [wir]."}, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q12953749", "label": null}]}
name: Morerebi

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "kav", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 lists two languages Kanamari [knm] and Katukina
[kav] as per the below.

| name | Kanamarí |
| Population | 1,330 (Moore 2006). 100 Tsohom-Djapa speakers (Crevels 2007) |
|  | Ethnic population: 2,750 (2006 FUNASA). |
| Location | Amazonas, upper regions of Jurua, Jutai, Itaquai rivers. |
| Language Use | Vigorous. |
| Language Status | 6a (Vigorous). |
| Language Maps | Western Central Brazil |
| ISO 639-3 | knm |
| Dialects | Tshom-Djapa (Txunhuã Dyapá, Txunhuã-Djapá), Tsohon-Djapa. |
| Country | Brazil |
| Classification | Maipurean, Southern, Southern Outlier, Piro |
| Alternate Names | Canamarí, Kanamaré |


| name | Katukína |
| Population | No known L1 speakers. Ethnic population: 590 (2008 FUNASA). |
| Other Comments | Different from Panoan Katukína [knt] in Amazonas and Acre. |
| Location | Acre. |
| Language Status | 9 (Dormant). |
| ISO 639-3 | kav |
| Dialects | Cutiadapa (Kutia-Dyapa). |
| Country | Brazil |
| Classification | Katukinan |
| Alternate Names | Catuquina, Katukina do Jutaí, Katukina do Rio Biá, Pidá-Djapá |


The language matching the name, location, population and dialect information of the Kanamari [knm] entry, is well-known from the linguistic (e.g.,
**hh:s:QueixalosdosAnjos:Katukina-Kanamari**, **hh:typ:Queixalos:Katukina**, **hh:s:Groth:Canamari**, **hh:phon:deMagalhaes:Kanamari**, **hh:hsoc:AnonbyHolbrook:Javari**, **hh:ew:Carvalho:Javari-Itacoai-Jurua**)
and ethnographic (e.g., **hh:he:Melatti:Javari**, **hh:he:Verneau:Amazon**)
literature. But this language is not, as the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 classification has it, a Maipurean Arawakan language closest to Piro (Yine)
[yib]. The idea that it is closely related to Piro ultimately stems from a name confusion with the Canamaré vocabulary in
**hh:hw:Martius:Brasiliens**. This Canamaré vocabulary is indeed so close to Piro as to count as Piro, but it is not the same language the Kanamari indicated by the data in the Kanamari [knm] entry, as shown already by **hh:vw:Rivet:Katukina**. Turning now to the Katukina
[kav]-entry, its location, classification, alternative names and dialect names (but not speaker number) corresponds to the Katukina known in the literature (e.g.,
**hh:phon:dosAnjos:Katukina**). However, this Katukina [kav]
language is mutually intelligible with Kanamari [knm]
(**hh:g:dosAnjos:Katukina-Kanamari**:8-16) and the two should count uncontroversially as one entry.  Older vocabularies are also similar enough to count as the same language
(**hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:vw:Rivet:Katukina**) so there is no reason to posit a separate entry for a Katukina that existed in the past. Thus,
one of the Kanamari [knm] and Katukina [kav] entries is spurious. The confusion in this case may have been licensed by the existence of yet more distinct languages surfacing under the name Katukina, i.e., the Panoan Katukina (**hh:hwsoc:deAguiar:Katukina**) and the problematic Catuquinarú vocabulary (**hh:vw:Rivet:Katukina**). See also: Katukína-Kanamarí [knm]."}, "links": [{"url": "http://endangeredlanguages.com/lang/4005", "label": "Katukina"}, {"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q3450636", "label": null}, {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katuk%C3%ADna_language", "label": null}, {"url": "https://phoible.org/languages/nucl1668", "label": null}], "meds": [["47381", "wordlist_or_less", 2005, 26, "Queixalós, Francesc 2005"], ["20802", "wordlist_or_less", 1993, 12, "Suelí Aguiar, Maria 1993"], ["83984", "wordlist_or_less", 1987, 0, "Resende, V.G. and S.M. Schmidt 1987"]]}
name: Katukína

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "paf", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "Of the languages of Tupi-Guarani subgroup VII,
there is considerable overdifferentiation.  Júma or Arara-Kawahib
[jua], Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz] and Karipúna (if it refers to Kawahib-Karipuna) [kuq] all speak easily mutually intelligible varieties
(**hh:hvw:Sampaio:Tupi-Kawahib**, **hh:e:Levi-Strauss:Tupi-Cawahib**, **hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**, **hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**, **hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**),
as also acknowledged by the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries themselves whose regions, dialects and speaker numbers overlap.  Paranawát [paf] is a name for a people of the same complex met with (and attested by wordlists) by the Rondon commission
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**). Morerebi [xmo] is an uncontacted group of the Rio Preto and Marmelos, who speak another variety of the this language, if they still exist (**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**).
Wiraféd [wir], also known as Tupi do Machado or Bocas Pretas, is amply attested in wordlists from the past century
(**hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Maue**, **hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hw:Nimuendaju:Icana**, **hh:w:Hanke:Parintintin**, **hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**)
and is hardly distinguishable from Apiaká [api]
(**hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**:222-223,
**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**), which also is so close that it could also count as the Kawahib-language. See also: Amundava [adw], Apiaká [api], Júma [jua], Karipúna [kuq], Morerebi [xmo], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz], Wiraféd [wir]."}, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q12953806", "label": null}], "meds": [["154958", "wordlist_or_less", 1948, 10, "Rondon, Cándido M. S. and de Faria, João Barbosa 1948"]]}
name: Paranawát

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "pok", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 has an entry for Pokangá [pok] as an Eastern Tucanoan language of the Upper Tiquié river in northwest Brazil. The entry contains the comment that ``The people claim to speak Waimaha
(Northern Barasano) [bao]''.  The Waimaha [bao] entry indeed has the Upper Tiquié river included in the list of locations. This area has been survey many times and there is no other Tucano language spoken there
(**hh:e:Jackson:Fish-People**, **hh:es:Giacone:Tucanos**, **hh:hw:Koch-Grunberg:Betoya**)
except Tucano [tuo] and Waimaha [bao] (also known as Bará), and the non-Tucano languages of the hunting-gathering peoples living between the larger rivers also have entries. The Pokangá [pok] entry is spurious, and should be merged with the Waimaha [bao] entry as the information in both already indicates. See also: Tucano [tuo], Waimaha [bao]."}, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q25559704", "label": null}]}
name: Pokangá

jsondata: {"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "slj", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "Salum\u00e1 [slj] is listed in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 as a separate Cariban language,\nbut the only two wordlists pertaining to a Cariban language with this name in the stated area is clearly Trio [tri]\n(**hh:g:Carlin:Trio**:8). If Salum\u00e1 is to be understood to refer to the group **hh:hv:Frikel:Nord-Para** calls Char\u00fama, then their language is that in the Waiwai [waw] entry. Either way, no separate Cariban language Salum\u00e1 [slj] can be asserted. See also: Tri\u00f3 [tri], Waiwai [waw]."}, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q7406296", "label": null}, {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Salum%C3%A1_language", "label": null}]}

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": {"code": "sap", "name": "Sanapaná", "change_request": "2013-013", "effective": "2014-02-03", "reason": "split", "change_to": ["spn", "aqt"], "remedy": "Split into Sanapaná [spn] and Angaité [aqt]", "comment": "Angaité and Sanapaná are different on all of the above criteria. Indeed, the
two languages are not mutually intelligible, and there is a clear ethnoliguistic
distinction.

The existing code element does not represent a major language. The Sanapaná and
Angaité languages are of equal standing in relation to each other and to the
other languages of the family. For example, comparing the differences between
Angaité and Sanapaná with those between Angaité and Enxet, the classification
of the two languages in a single code element is clearly arbitrary."}, "ethnologue_comment": null, "links": [], "meds": [["136283", "phonology_or_text", 1973, 36, "Cordeu, Edgardo J. 1973"], ["15065", "wordlist_or_less", 1941, 59, "Becker, Hans von 1941"]]}

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "urz", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "Of the languages of Tupi-Guarani subgroup VII,
there is considerable overdifferentiation.  Júma or Arara-Kawahib
[jua], Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz] and Karipúna (if it refers to Kawahib-Karipuna) [kuq] all speak easily mutually intelligible varieties
(**hh:hvw:Sampaio:Tupi-Kawahib**, **hh:e:Levi-Strauss:Tupi-Cawahib**, **hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**, **hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**, **hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**),
as also acknowledged by the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries themselves whose regions, dialects and speaker numbers overlap.  Paranawát [paf] is a name for a people of the same complex met with (and attested by wordlists) by the Rondon commission
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**). Morerebi [xmo] is an uncontacted group of the Rio Preto and Marmelos, who speak another variety of the this language, if they still exist (**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**).
Wiraféd [wir], also known as Tupi do Machado or Bocas Pretas, is amply attested in wordlists from the past century
(**hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Maue**, **hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hw:Nimuendaju:Icana**, **hh:w:Hanke:Parintintin**, **hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**)
and is hardly distinguishable from Apiaká [api]
(**hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**:222-223,
**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**), which also is so close that it could also count as the Kawahib-language. See also: Amundava [adw], Apiaká [api], Júma [jua], Karipúna [kuq], Morerebi [xmo], Paranawát [paf], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah], Wiraféd [wir]."}, "links": [{"url": "http://endangeredlanguages.com/lang/1957", "label": "Uruewawau"}, {"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q10266012", "label": null}, {"url": "https://phoible.org/languages/urue1240", "label": null}], "meds": [["557756", "grammar_sketch", 2015, 0, "Vezzaro, Antônia de Fátima Galdino da Silva 2015"], ["583188", "phonology_or_text", 2014, 19, "Antônia de Fátima Galdino da Silva Vezzaro 2014"], ["309049", "wordlist_or_less", 2012, 60, "Betts, LaVera 2012"], ["22397", "wordlist_or_less", 1997, 12, "Sampaio, Wany Bernadete de Araujo 1997"], ["325838", "wordlist_or_less", 1981, 34, "Arruda da Costa, Maria 1981-1984"]]}

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "NOCODE_Warekena-Velha", "comment_type": "missing", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "Some confusion is related to Arawakan languages surfacing under the names Baniwa and Warekena. Four languages can be argued to exist. One language most closely related to Yavitero which may be called Baniva de Maroa or Baniva de Guainía (but called Warekena [do rio Xié] in **hh:g:Aikhenvald:Warekena**) which fits best with the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entry of Guarequena [gae]. Another language called Baniva is extinct and attested only with a tiny wordlist in
**hh:hew:Gilij:Americana**:V3:203-204 but was probably close to Maipure. Especially given the alternative name Avani, it matches the entry Baniva [bvv] in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24. Yet another large language called Baniwa do Içana is reflected in E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24's entry Baniwa do Icana [bwi] and is closely related to (if not part of the same language as) Curripaco [kpc]. Finally, a language which may be called Warekena Velha or Old Warekena is described in
(**hh:g:Gonzalez:Warekena**) is most closely related to Mandahuaca
[mht] (**hh:hvw:Ramirez:Arawak**:329-349). Warekena Velha is missing from E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24. See also: Avane [bvv], Baniva de Maroa [gae], Baniwa do Icana [bwi], Curripaco [kpc], Mandahuaca [mht]."}, "links": [], "meds": [["556776", "grammar", 2009, 287, "González Ñáñez, Omar 2009"], ["302617", "grammar", 1997, 0, "González Ñáñez, Omar 1997"], ["149575", "phonology_or_text", 1975, 286, "González Ñañez, Omar 1975"], ["131663", "wordlist_or_less", 1974, 10, "González Ñáñez, Omar 1974-1975"], ["126499", "wordlist_or_less", 1950, 10, "de Civrieux, Marc and René Lichy 1950"], ["98758", "wordlist_or_less", 1911, 10, "Theodor Koch-Grünberg 1911"], ["471826", "wordlist_or_less", 1831, 5, "Christiane Cunha de Oliveira 2012 [1831]"]]}

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "wir", "comment_type": "spurious", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "Of the languages of Tupi-Guarani subgroup VII,
there is considerable overdifferentiation.  Júma or Arara-Kawahib
[jua], Amundava [adw], Tenharim [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz] and Karipúna (if it refers to Kawahib-Karipuna) [kuq] all speak easily mutually intelligible varieties
(**hh:hvw:Sampaio:Tupi-Kawahib**, **hh:e:Levi-Strauss:Tupi-Cawahib**, **hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**, **hh:e:Leonel:Urueu-au-au**, **hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**),
as also acknowledged by the E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries themselves whose regions, dialects and speaker numbers overlap.  Paranawát [paf] is a name for a people of the same complex met with (and attested by wordlists) by the Rondon commission
(**hh:hw:Rondon:Silvicolas**). Morerebi [xmo] is an uncontacted group of the Rio Preto and Marmelos, who speak another variety of the this language, if they still exist (**hh:e:Kastner:Urueuwauwau**).
Wiraféd [wir], also known as Tupi do Machado or Bocas Pretas, is amply attested in wordlists from the past century
(**hh:w:Koch-Grunberg:Maue**, **hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hw:Nimuendaju:Icana**, **hh:w:Hanke:Parintintin**, **hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**)
and is hardly distinguishable from Apiaká [api]
(**hh:w:NimuendajudoValleVentes:Peu**:222-223,
**hh:h:Loukotka:Tupi-Guarani**), which also is so close that it could also count as the Kawahib-language. See also: Amundava [adw], Apiaká [api], Júma [jua], Karipúna [kuq], Morerebi [xmo], Paranawát [paf], Tenharim-Parintintin-Diahoi [pah], Uru-Eu-Wau-Wau [urz]."}, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q12953970", "label": null}], "meds": [["145192", "wordlist_or_less", 1953, 12, "Hanke, Wanda 1953"], ["63895", "wordlist_or_less", 1932, 7, "Theodor Koch-Grünberg 1932"]]}
name: Wiraféd

jsondata:
{"iso_retirement": null, "ethnologue_comment": {"isohid": "NOCODE_Xoco", "comment_type": "missing", "ethnologue_versions": ["E16", "E17", "E18", "E19", "E20", "E21", "E22", "E23", "E24"], "comment": "Ethnologue (editions 16-19) has two entries Karirí-Xocó [kzw] and Xukurú [xoo],
with the following information:

| p{5cm} p{5cm}} | Karirí-Xocó [kzw] | Xukurú [xoo] |
| Dialects: | Kipeá (Quipea), Kamurú (Camuru), Dzubukuá (Dzubucua), Sabujá (Pedra Branca). Other dialects or languages are even less well attested. |  |
| Region: | Alagoas. | Pernambuco, Serra de Urubá (Arobá) near Cimbres City, Bahía. |
| Classification: | Unclassified | Unclassified |
| Language development: | Grammar. |  |
| country: | Brazil | Brazil |
| Alternate names: | Karirí, Kariri Xucó, Kipeá, Xocó, Xokó, Xokó-Karirí, Xukurú, Xukuru Kariri | Kirirí, Kirirí-Xokó |
| Population: | No known speakers. Ethnic population: 1,062 (1995 SIL). | No known speakers. Ethnic population: 6,363. |
| Language use: | Shifted to Portuguese. | Shifted to Portuguese. |


The are (at least) three attested languages relevant for these two entries. The first, which we may call Kipeá-Dzubukuá, is a dialect complex consisting of Dzubukuá, Kipeá, Kamurú (Camuru), Sabujá
for which Jesuits grammars/catechisms are the main source of documentation. Quite a lot is known about Kipeá-Dzubukuá grammar,
i.e., noun classes, VSO constituent order, ergativity and so on
(**hh:s:Mamiani:Kiriri**, **hh:s:Azevedo:Kiriri**, **hh:hvs:Adam:Kariri**, **hh:typ:Larsen:Kiriri**, **hh:hv:Rodrigues:Macro-Je**, **hh:typ:Rodrigues:Kariri**, **hh:t:deNantes:Kariris**, **hh:phonw:deQuieroz:Dzubukua**). The second, which we may call Chocó, is attested only in a few minuscule wordlists
(**hh:w:Loukotka:Inedits**, **hh:hv:PompeuSobrinho:Tapuias-NE**, **hh:ld:Pompeu:Tapuias**).
The third, which we may call Shucurú, is attested only in a few wordlists
(**hh:hvw:Loukotka:Inconnues**, **hh:w:Lapenda:Xucuru**, **hh:hw:Meader:Nordeste**).
Whatever the meagre data of Chocó and Shukurú tell us, it does not support any constellation of Chocó, Shukurú or Kipeá-Dzubukuá
being the same language or the same family
(**hh:hv:Loukotka:Non-Tupi-NEBresil**, **hh:hv:Loukotka:SAmerica**). The Chocó lived in Alagoas when first mentioned in the literature,
whereas no variety of Kipeá-Dzubukuá or Shucurú is attested in Alagoas before the 20th century
(**hh:e:Hohenthal:Shucuru**, **hh:hv:Loukotka:Non-Tupi-NEBresil**, **hh:h:Nimuendaju:Etno-Historico**). The descendants of Chocó, Shucurú, Kipeá-Dzubukuá (and other tribes) were subsequently missionized together in various places and constellations, to the end that, at present, they could be considered one group from an ethnographic perspective
(**hh:e:Carneiro:Kariri-Shoco**) who speak only Portuguese and with Alagoas as one of its locations. However, E16/E17/E18/E19/E20/E21/E22/E23/E24 entries are supposed to reflect languages rather than ethnicities, so the information in the Karirí-Xocó [kzw] and Xukurú [xoo] entries are, at best,
anachronistic. Ideally, a new entry should be created for Chocó (it was probably extinct by 1951, but, except for rememberers, all three were probably extinct by 1951), and the names and locations of the Kipeá-Dzubukuá [kzw] and Xukurú [xoo] entries should be changed to reflect the names and locations of the (past) speakers of the language of the entry, rather than the names and locations used for descendants who do not speak the language of the entry. See also: Karirí-Xocó [kzw], Xukurú [xoo]."}, "links": [{"url": "https://www.wikidata.org/entity/Q12953620", "label": null}, {"url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xoc%C3%B3_language", "label": null}], "meds": [["161469", "wordlist_or_less", 1963, 1, "Čestmír Loukotka 1963"], ["132591", "wordlist_or_less", 1939, 2, "Pompeu Sobrinho, Thomas 1939"], ["89351", "wordlist_or_less", 1883, 17, "de Frescarolo, Vital 1883"], ["148020", "wordlist_or_less", 1867, 0, "Martius, C.F.P. von 1867"], ["150979", "wordlist_or_less", 1846, 0, "Gardner, George 1846"]]}
name: Xoco
